awd_titl_txt: Conference: 2024 Eastern States Section Meeting of the Combustion Institute
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this award is to provide support for the 2024 Spring Technical Meeting of the Eastern States Section of the Combustion Institute will be hosted by the University of Georgia, Athens, GA, commencing the evening of Sunday, March 10, 2024, and concluding at noon on Wednesday, March 13, 2024. The broader significance and importance of this meeting is providing a forum for graduate students, postdoctoral students, faculty and other researchers to network and share progress in this area of research. This conference is a gathering of combustion researchers in academia, industry, and government from the East Coast region of the United States. The conference's technical program consists of a series of plenary lectures, contributed oral presentations, and information social gatherings. Many of the papers will be presented by students and the meeting is an opportunity for students to network with their peers and faculty from other institutions. A goal of the meeting is to expose students to the latest research and offer opportunity for career development.

The conference brings together leading experts to give plenary talks in several areas. Sessions will include the topic areas of Computationally and Data Intensive Research, Detonations and Supersonic Combustion, Diagnostics, Fire Research, Heterogeneous Combustion/Spray and Droplets, IC Engines, Gas Turbines, and Rockets, Laminar Flames, Novel Energy Conversion Techniques, Reaction Kinetics and Fuels, Soot and Nanomaterials, Turbulent Flames. A particular focus of this conference is on graduate and undergraduate students: providing an opportunity for these students to present and get feedback on their research and enhancing their oral presentation and technical writing skills. The support from NSF will be used to award travel grants to non-local students and registration support for local students in an effort to increase student participation at the meeting, particularly students from underrepresented institutions that may not have the financial means to fully support student travel to conferences. Hence the conference will support the training of future workforce in combustion and related field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A particular focus of this conference was on graduate and undergraduate students: providing an opportunity for these students to practice technical writing skills, deliver a research presentation and receive feedback, and build their professional networks. The support from NSF was used in part for travel grants to non-local students and registration support for local students in an effort to increase student participation at the meeting, particularly students from underrepresented institutions that may not have the financial means to fully support students travel to conferences. Hence the conference supported the training of future workforce in combustion and related field.

A new ‘industry panel session’ was included in the 2024 ESSCI meeting at the University of Georgia that involved 3 researchers from industry discussing their view of issues relevant to the themes of the meeting, such as energy sustainability, emissions mitigation, fire safety, and other topics. The aim of this event was to host a catered dinner for graduate students who are participating in the conference, which provided opportunities for industry leaders to communicate their own views and that of their companies as it relates to the importance of combustion. The event also provided additional opportunities for career advice and direct engagement with professionals working in a range of industries, including energy, defense, and fire safety analysis.

The ESSCI conference banquet was held at the State Botanical Gardens of Georgia in the Great Room. As a unit of Public Service and Outreach at the University of Georgia, the State Botanical Garden of Georgia created an environment for learning, inspiration and engagement through horticulture, conservation, science-based programs and lasting partnerships. The State Botanical Garden's tropical collection surrounds the Great Room (where the banquet was held) year-round and with high glass ceilings and exotic greenery, the setting becomes more spectacular after sunset.

Several key plenary speakers were featured at the conference. Dr. Tim Lieuwen is the Regents’ Professor, holder of the David S. Lewis, Jr. Chair, and the executive director of the Strategic Energy Institute at Georgia Tech presented on topics of clean energy and propulsion systems, energy policy, acoustics, fluid mechanics, and combustion. Prof. Jillian Goldfarb (Cornell University) discussed the designing of new processes to convert renewable sources to energy and materials that remove such pollutants. Examples included ongoing research projects include investigating the conversion of biomass to biofuels via pyrolysis and hydrothermal carbonization, fabricating sustainable materials for water treatment, and designing slow-release soil amendments from waste biomass. Dr. Sibendu Som (Argonne National Laboratory) presented research as Interim Director for the Center for Advanced Propulsion and Power in the Transportation and Power Systems Division at Argonne National Laboratory. Dr. Som discussed several computational models his team developed that are part of commercial computational codes, which leveraged the latest developments in high-performance computing and machine learning to accelerate these high-fidelity simulations. The 7th Glassman lecture was delivered by Dr. Sili Deng (MIT). Dr. Deng discussed scientific machine learning for reacting flows, and flame synthesis of materials for catalysis and energy storage.
